body:
Forgot to indicate last commit 80a9aa20148fdd41100d0afb2fad3243d543a25e closed this.

Thanks for the fix @abpoms!
I did i bunch of changes. I believe is ready for rock and roll! Thanks a lot!
I've added also a fix for worldwidedns docs.

Thanks.  LGTM.

As discussed on the IRC - eventually we will want the same behavior in other drivers such as OpenStack and CloudStack. OpenStack + Neutron without nova networking results in a similar default behavior (no public IP by default).
Merged, thanks.

I made a change to the `PointDNSException` class so it inherits from `ProviderError` which is intended to be used for that purpose - 08556656a7d69ad3d5c696f14d8d41b95373c5ee. I also updated the constructor signature so it matches the parent one.

For the future reference - this class doesn't really provide additional value over the existing `ProviderError` one (all the information is already available via ProviderError class) so there is little value in adding / having it.

Besides that the changes look good so I've merged it into trunk.

Thanks.

Great, merged.

Thanks!
Yeah, you're right. My intention only was to specify the provider. If for some reason someone needs to catch an exception only for pointdns, can use it. But, yeah. Is just a little thing.
Thanks for the merges!
Update on this?
@Kami ICLA is signed and filed :).

@A1fus Thanks, but those documentation files are generated automatically by scripts in ./contrib directory and they shouldn't be edited manually so sorry, we can't merge this.

If you are looking for some other low hanging fruit you can go over the docs, I'm pretty sure there are plently of typos and grammar errors which need to be fixed :)

Thanks, but we are using restructered text and not Markdown which uses a different link syntax.

You can find an example of the link syntax - http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/user/rst/quickref.html#external-hyperlink-targets

Merged, thanks!

Sorry for the delay - I went ahead and merged the changes.

For now, lets keep `kwargs`, but in the future it would be great if we can get rid of it and explicitly declare all the supported arguments - (ab)using kwargs makes many things such as "static" analysis hard / impossible.

On a related note - I just went over the drivers again and noticed some more issues:
1. `create_zone` method signature in Liquidweb DNS driver doesn't conform to the base DNS API
2. `create_zone` method signature in DNSimple DNS driver doesn't conform to the base DNS API

@aleGpereira Can you please also address those issues? Thanks!

It looks like there are a lot more typos of the same nature, would be great if you can fix them all :)

``` bash
kami ~/w/lc/libcloud (git:trunk)$ ag "bellow" | wc -l
42
```
@Kami Done. #601. For some reasons travis took too much time. I couldn't see yet if build was passing. But it should be fine.

I went ahead, merged your fix and fixed other 42 typos myself :)

Thanks
Merged, thanks :)

I saw this mentioned in irc today as not making the release.  Afaict, @thesquelched addressed all the issues brought up.  If there's additional feedback, please let him have it so we can get this fixed.

Thanks, but for this actually to work you also need to update the driver to use this information.

See:
1. https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/softlayer.py#L441
2. https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/cloudsigma.py#L251 - an example of how to retrieve the size pricing from the pricing file

Thanks.

Merged, thanks!
/cc @aleGpereira
@Kami @phumpal isn't the extra dictionary suppose to be driver specific?

@aleGpereira Correct, although (sadly), right now some "standard" values in the DNS drivers are passed via the extra dictionary - notably "priority" for MX records and ttl.

I hope to eventually refactor / fix that by moving it from the extra dictionary to the method argument.
:+1: thanks @Kami ! I look forward to the refactor / fix :smile:
@Kami @phumpal  Alright. What matters is that it works!
Yeah sure!

So does the Openstack test cases use rackspace driver in the backend? Because in my test case for the above code, I call the `driver.ex_list_subnets` function which throws an error saying this function is undefined in `RackspaceFirstGenNodeDriver` .  
I agree that Rackspace runs on OpenStack, but shouldn't these tests be performed on a running devstack instance?
Why did this get closed?

Because it's outdated. Unfortunately the documentation hasn't been updated to reflect the change in the API though, and I only realised after making the PR that the documentation is outdated and my PR redundant.

The change is (mentioned [here](https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/changelog.html#changes-with-apache-libcloud-0-14-0-beta3)) is:

> Deprecate the following EC2 provider constants: EC2_US_EAST, EC2_EU, EC2_EU_WEST, EC2_AP_SOUTHEAST, EC2_AP_NORTHEAST, EC2_US_WEST_OREGON, EC2_SA_EAST, EC2_SA_EAST and replace it with a new EC2 constant. Driver referenced by this new constant now takes a region argument which dictates to which region to connect.

So the following example (lifted from the docs):

```
cls = get_driver(Provider.EC2_US_WEST)
driver = cls('temporary access key', 'temporary secret key', token='temporary session token')
```

becomes:

```
cls = get_driver(Provider.EC2)
driver = cls("auth key", "auth secret", token="token", region="us-west-1")
```

So the driver type is no longer used to determine the location which the driver connects to. Instead, if you specify a valid region, that is the region it connects to. Valid regions are: 
- eu-west-1
- sa-east-1
- ap-southeast-2
- us-west-1
- us-east-1
- ap-southeast-1
- ap-northeast-1
- us-gov-west-1
- eu-central-1
- us-west-2
I've opened #606 to fix the docs.
Thanks @JamesGuthrie.  I wandered down the same path you did!
No problem! Hopefully you will be the last to do so.

Thanks :)

Changes look good to me so I will go ahead and merge them.
Merged, thanks.
thanks @EfrenRey the PR is closed but I will fix these issues separately. good catch. these methods are really repetitive!

Thanks.

I'm fine with that change, but it will break if Travis CI drops support for some Python version we still support, right?

In short - I'm fine with merging it, but we will need to revert this change in case Travis drops support for a Python version so we just need to document that - I guess we can just add a comment to the travis yaml file.

Hi @davidwilson2038, thanks for this!

Although I don't know of any actual differences off the top of my head, GCE's pricing _can_ vary by region.  We also have a pricing calculator that can be used to get the most current price list.

Regarding format of the pricing file, this varies a bit from what is proposed in #464?  I likely need to just get this updated and merged. What do you think about going with that PR vs this one?
@erjohnso I like #464 , as its more complete. It might not work with the test from my commit, as I had to add in the deprecated instance names to work get it work with the test fixtures.

@davidwilson2038 - ok, let's go with #464 then.  We're stepping through the release process for 0.19.0 right now and I'll get #464 merged in right after that.

Feel free to close this one out and thanks again!

@mbrukman That is probably a good question for @erjohnso .  Also, one other thing...I jumped the gun on my previous comments...just realized the other drivers use the name of the driver + region name for the name on the pricing json if they have different prices for regions. (e.g. ec2_ap_northeast). Having the region nested in the json as you have currently should break the _get_size_price method when called for list_sizes in the driver. To get this to work, we need to change the list_sizes method and have each region be its own entry in the json file (ie google_asia or google_europe, etc.)
The build seems to fail, but I don't think it's related to this PR?
@runseb Can you take a look?
@runseb Can you take a look?

@atsaki do you plan to work on this ? @allardhoeve made some good comments, could you answer ?thanks
